name: Rental unit in Vancouver · ★5.0 · 1 bedroom · 1 bed · 1 bath
neighborhood_overview: Le Soleil Hotel and Suites is situated in the heart of Vancouver's hotel and entertainment district and is steps away from restaurants, shopping, and transportation services. The building is a 5-minute walk (370m) from the Vancouver Convention Centre and a 4-minute walk (300m) from the Vancouver Art Gallery and Pacific Centre Mall. The Burrard Skytrain Station, Canada Place, Coal Harbour, and the Sea Wall are just steps away. Slightly further out you will find historic Gastown, the Robson shopping district, the charming West End, Stanley Park and many beautiful beaches. There is also no limit to the delicious food and drink that can be found in the many eateries downtown. Alouette French Bistro is located next to the hotel lobby, offering a selection of à la carte breakfast, lunch, and dinner options. Vancouver International Airport (YVR) is located 15 away and is accessible from the hotel by either a 20-minute taxi ride or a 30-minute skytrain ride from nearby stations.

name: Condo in Vancouver · ★4.88 · Studio · 1 bed · 1 bath
neighborhood_overview:
Vancouver's vibrant West End is located at the west end of downtown Vancouver, just east of Stanley Park and Lost Lagoon. The West End is surrounded by water on three sides: English Bay, Coal Harbour, and Lost Lagoon in world-famous Stanley Park.

Safeway and Whole Foods are both within a two-minute / 140m / .08mi walk from the building's front door. The entrance to Stanley Park is just a seven-minute / 550m / 0.34mi walk from the building's front door.

The West End is the heart of Vancouver's LGBTQ2S+ community, including Davie Village and Denman Street, which together provide local shopping and restaurants. This area also has high-end retail and boutique shopping on Robson Street and Alberni Street. The night life, movie theatres, and intimate concert venues on Granville Street are just a 20 minute / 1.7km / 1mi walk away.

Vancouver’s own Kitsilano Beach, located in its namesake neighbourhood, has been crowned the best urban beach in Canada.

name: Home in Vancouver · ★5.0 · 2 bedrooms · 2 beds · 1.5 baths
neighborhood_overview: In the 1960s, Kitsilano, a coastal neighbourhood in Vancouver, served as the Haight-Ashbury of the West Coast. Kitsilano still has a vibrant cultural scene today, but young urban professionals and families now live there and enjoy a more upbeat version of the neighbourhood's laid-back vibe. Kitsilano is also the birthplace of the well-known yoga clothing company lululemon athletica. The neighbourhood, which is just over the Burrard Bridge from the downtown peninsula, brings together a variety of attractions, beaches, and parks, as well as residential streets and a few major business areas. The waterfront and West 16th Avenue are to the north and south, respectively, of "Kits," as it is referred to locally. Burrard Street and Alma Street are to the east and west, respectively. Most of the commercial activity is along West 4th Avenue and West Broadway, but you’ll also find shops and restaurants in the areas close to the beach.

Day or evening, The Drive offers 22 full blocks to explore with over 300 distinct merchants, including quaint boutiques, an eclectic collection of restaurants, a vibrant live music and bar scene, dinner and dancing, theatres, coffee houses, specialty food stores and bakeries. A one of a kind experience. Welcome to The Drive.

Shaughnessy is strategically located in the centre of Vancouver but is considered to also be at the core of Vancouver’s Westside, near major arteries for car and transit access to anywhere one would need to go.

Many of Shaughnessy’s original homes were designed by the city’s top architects, who infused the neighbourhood with classic British and early American architectural influences that can still be seen today.

Some preferred leisure activities in this neighbourhood are strolling, jogging or biking through the community itself. Shaughnessy encompasses several heritage properties designed to be admired, including the Hycroft and Glen Brae (now home to Canuck Place, a children’s hospice). Among Shaughnessy’s four public parks is the 55-acre VanDusen Botanical Gardens, an everchanging showcase of the community’s gardening acumen.

neighborhood_overview:
Lonely Planet names Commercial Drive one of world's coolest neighborhoods. It's known as Vancouver's Little Italy.
You won’t find many franchises nor all too many tourists along this east-side strip and its offshoot streets, and there’s nary a glass tower nor souped-up Lamborghini in sight. Instead, there are humble street-level boutiques, lively cafes, patios and pubs, and a pervasive artsy, counter-cultural vibe. Add to the mix some old-school and modern Italian restaurants, delis and gelato shops, along with every other type of world cuisine imaginable- and you have a recipe for a mellow day of strolling, shopping, sipping and savoring in one of the city’s unique walkable neighborhoods.
Easily accessible by SKYTRAIN, Commercial Drive prides itself on being a hip, artistic residential neighborhood that's minutes to downtown.

Kitsilano, often called "Kits," is a vibrant and trendy neighborhood located in the west side of Vancouver.
Kitsilano is known for its picturesque beaches, parks, and stunning views of the mountains and the ocean. Some of the most popular beaches in Kitsilano include Kitsilano Beach, Jericho Beach, and Spanish Banks Beach. Kitsilano Beach is particularly famous for its outdoor pool, which is open to the public from May to September each year.

The neighborhood is also home to a diverse range of shops, restaurants, cafes, and bars, many of which are located along West 4th Avenue, also known as "Kitsilano's trendy shopping district,” or West Broadway. The area is very lively with plenty of options for entertainment and socializing.

Kitsilano is a popular residential area, with a mix of heritage homes, modern condos, and apartments. It attracts a diverse population, including families, young professionals, and students from nearby universities.

Mount Pleasant is one of Vancouver's most desirable and central neighbourhoods. It is a short walk to the Broadway and Cambie transit hub, Vancouver General Hospital, City Hall, Olympic Village Seawall, trendy Main Street breweries and cafes, and the Mount Pleasant tech hub. It is also a short and direct commute to downtown.

Mount Pleasant is Vancouver’s oldest neighbourhood outside downtown and includes a distinct collection of small businesses, community and arts organizations, and residents from all social and economic backgrounds. The rich residential, commercial and industrial heritage of the area weaves together a variety of cultures and economic backgrounds, to create an intriguing collection of community memories and stories that date back to the early 1900s.

neighborhood_overview:
Kitsilano, often called "Kits," is a vibrant and trendy neighborhood located in the west side of Vancouver.
Kitsilano is known for its picturesque beaches, parks, and stunning views of the mountains and the ocean. Some of the most popular beaches in Kitsilano include Kitsilano Beach, Jericho Beach, and Spanish Banks Beach. Kitsilano Beach is particularly famous for its outdoor pool, which is open to the public from May to September each year.

The neighborhood is also home to a diverse range of shops, restaurants, cafes, and bars, many of which are located along West 4th Avenue, also known as "Kitsilano's trendy shopping district,” or West Broadway. The area is very lively with plenty of options for entertainment and socializing.

Kitsilano is a popular residential area, with a mix of heritage homes, modern condos, and apartments. It attracts a diverse population, including families, young professionals, and students from nearby universities.

Vancouver's West End is a vibrant and diverse neighborhood located on the western edge of downtown Vancouver. Known for its beautiful beaches, stunning views, and abundance of green space, the West End is a popular destination for both locals and visitors alike.

The West End is such a great neighborhood and has some amazing things to see and do.

Visit English Bay Beach: This popular beach is located on the northern edge of the West End and is known for its beautiful sunsets and clear waters. It's a great spot for swimming, sunbathing, and beach volleyball.

Explore Stanley Park: This huge urban park is located at the western tip of the West End and is home to a variety of recreational activities, including hiking and biking trails, an aquarium, and a miniature train.

Walk along the Seawall: The Seawall is a popular walking and biking path that winds around Stanley Park and offers stunning views of the ocean and the city.

name: Rental unit in Vancouver · 4 bedrooms · 4 beds · 3.5 baths
neighborhood_overview:
Overview
Yaletown was once the Western terminus for the Canadian Pacific Railway, but the area’s more recent reinvention dates back to 1986 when the waterfront along the north of False Creek was host to many of the venues when Vancouver hosted the World’s Fair. Since then that land, along with the warehouse district adjoining it have been transformed into one of the city’s chicest neighbourhoods, filled with residential loft spaces, sidewalk cafes, cool restaurants, unique shopping, and leafy parks. Sitting along the south side of the downtown Vancouver peninsula, Yaletown is bordered by Homer Street, Robson Street and False Creek.

Seeing and Doing
The waterfront parks are a big draw in Yaletown. The city’s seawall runs right along the water, connecting two of the biggest green spaces: David Lam Park and George Wainborn Park. Walk, jog, bike or inline skate along the Seawall and you’ll find plenty of locals doing the same and enjoying the excellent public art sprin

neighborhood_overview:
Yaletown was once the Western terminus for the Canadian Pacific Railway, but the area’s more recent reinvention dates back to 1986 when the waterfront along the north of False Creek was host to many of the venues when Vancouver hosted the World’s Fair. Since then that land, along with the warehouse district adjoining it have been transformed into one of the city’s chicest neighbourhoods, filled with residential loft spaces, sidewalk cafes, cool restaurants, unique shopping, and leafy parks. Sitting along the south side of the downtown Vancouver peninsula, Yaletown is bordered by Homer Street, Robson Street and False Creek.


Seeing and Doing
The waterfront parks are a big draw in Yaletown. The city’s seawall runs right along the water, connecting two of the biggest green spaces: David Lam Park and George Wainborn Park. Walk, jog, bike or inline skate along the Seawall and you’ll find plenty of locals doing the same and enjoying the excellent public art sprinkled al

neighborhood_overview:
THE ORIGINAL VANCOUVER

Established around the area’s first tavern, Gastown is the heart of Vancouver. It was designated a National Historic Site in 2009, and offers a saw tooth skyline that dates back to the 1800s, showcasing some of the city’s best Victorian Italianate, Edwardian Commercial and Romanesque architecture.

Gastown is central to Vancouver’s position as one of the most cosmopolitan cities in the world, providing a rich, textured backdrop for the neighbourhoods vanguard group of entrepreneurs.

Offering a thriving fashion district, impeccably curated décor boutiques, one-of-a-kind galleries and some of the best culinary fare in the city. But step up from street level and you’ll also find a collection of the city’s most creative enterprises, from graphic designers and architects to film students and photographers.

It’s no surprise that in 2012, Gastown was named the fourth most stylish neighbourhood in the world, setting trends from

neighborhood_overview:
Downtown Vancouver is a vibrant and bustling urban core of the city, offering a unique blend of culture, entertainment, and natural beauty. As the economic and cultural heart of the city, it is a must-visit destination for tourists from around the world.

One of the most striking features of downtown Vancouver is its location between the Pacific Ocean and the Coastal Mountains, which provides visitors with stunning views of the water and mountains from almost every angle. Stanley Park, located on the city's western edge, is one of the largest urban parks in North America and offers an incredible array of outdoor activities and sightseeing opportunities.

Downtown Vancouver is also home to a number of cultural attractions, including the Vancouver Art Gallery, the Museum of Anthropology at the University of British Columbia, and the Vancouver Aquarium. Visitors can explore the city's rich history and cultural diversity by exploring its many art galleries, museums, and

neighborhood_overview:
In the 1960s, beachside Kitsilano was Vancouver's hippy hangout, drawing comparisons to San Francisco's Haight-Ashbury. Today, Kitsilano still has plenty of culture, but its apartments and houses are now occupied by young urban professionals and families who enjoy a modern version of that relaxed atmosphere – this is the birthplace of global yoga brand, lululemon athletica. Just over the Burrard Bridge from the downtown peninsula, the neighbourhood brings together a collection of attractions, beach and parks, residential streets, and a couple of main commercial districts. “Kits,” as it’s known locally, is bordered by the waterfront to the north and West 16th Ave to the south; Burrard Street to the east and Alma Street to the west. Most of the commercial activity is along West 4th Avenue and West Broadway, but you’ll also find shops and restaurants in the areas close to the beach.

From Burrard Bridge, look north and you’ll glimpse a large waterfront greenspace known as Vanier

A beach in British Columbia has been named one of the best in Canada, and it’s right here in Vancouver.

Travel publisher Lonely Planet has released its list of the top 10 beaches in the country, and BC has come up swimmingly.

Instead of ranking each beach from one to 10, though, each sandy spot has been given its own “best of” title.

Vancouver’s own Kitsilano Beach, located in its namesake neighbourhood, has been crowned the best urban beach in Canada.


“A freewheeling nugget of Southern California chopped off and transported one thousand miles north,” Lonely Planet writes. “The yellow arc of sand is sugary and clean.”

“Backed by cool cafes and an attractive park, Kits exudes a sporty, laid-back vibe, especially in summer.”

neighborhood_overview:
Gastown and Waterfront Vancouver are two of the most vibrant and exciting neighbourhoods in the city. Located in the heart of downtown, the area is a hub of activity, with countless restaurants, bars, cafes, and shops.

Gastown is the oldest neighbourhood in Vancouver and has a rich history of culture and industry. The historic buildings, cobblestone streets, and gas lamps create an atmosphere of nostalgia and romance. Gastown is home to a variety of unique boutiques, galleries, and eateries.

Waterfront Vancouver is the city's waterfront neighbourhood, located along the shore of False Creek. It is a vibrant and bustling area, with a variety of attractions, events, and activities. Visitors can explore the bustling harbour, hop on a ferry to Granville Island, or take a stroll along the waterfront promenade. From street performers to seafood restaurants, Waterfront Vancouver offers something for everyone.

neighborhood_overview:
Overview
Despite the fact that Coal Harbour is right downtown, it’s a surprisingly calm little neighbourhood, right on the water’s edge. It’s even more surprising given its industrial history as a former shipyard sitting right next to the railway terminus. The area starts at Canada Place and stretches west to Stanley Park, and is bordered by Burrard Inlet to the north, West Georgia Street to the south. Coal Harbour is a charming mix of business and residential, being home to both the Vancouver Convention Centre as well as condo towers. Around this area you’ll find locals and visitors mingling on the Seawall, neighbourhood cafes and restaurants, a popular marina, and the odd harbour seal bobbing around and greeting passersby.

name: Rental unit in Vancouver · 2 bedrooms · 2 beds · 1 bath
neighborhood_overview:
Kitsilano, often called "Kits," is a vibrant and trendy neighborhood located in the west side of Vancouver.

Kitsilano is known for its picturesque beaches, parks, and stunning views of the mountains and the ocean. Some of the most popular beaches in Kitsilano include Kitsilano Beach, Jericho Beach, and Spanish Banks Beach. Kitsilano Beach is particularly famous for its outdoor pool, which is open to the public from May to September each year.

The neighborhood is also home to a diverse range of shops, restaurants, cafes, and bars, many of which are located along West 4th Avenue, also known as "Kitsilano's trendy shopping district,” or West Broadway. The area is very lively with plenty of options for entertainment and socializing.

Kitsilano is a popular residential area, with a mix of heritage homes, modern condos, and apartments. It attracts a diverse population, including families, young professionals, and students from nearby universities.

neighborhood_overview:
41st Avenue and Victoria Street find themselves in the heart of Vancouver, a city steeped in history and cultural significance. The region was once home to indigenous communities like the Musqueam, Squamish, and Tsleil-Waututh Nations, whose presence can still be felt in the area's landmarks and place names.

One of the defining features of this neighborhood is its cultural diversity. A melting pot of various ethnicities, it celebrates a tapestry of traditions, languages, and cuisines. Walking along 41st Avenue and Victoria Street, one can encounter a delightful array of restaurants, shops, and markets offering delicacies from around the globe.

As a microcosm of Vancouver's charm and character, this thriving urban hub continues to captivate the hearts of those who call it home or simply visit to experience its unique magic.

Yaletown was once the Western terminus for the Canadian Pacific Railway, but the area’s more recent reinvention dates back to 1986 when the waterfront along the north of False Creek was host to many of the venues when Vancouver hosted the World’s Fair. Since then that land, along with the warehouse district adjoining it have been transformed into one of the city’s chicest neighbourhoods, filled with residential loft spaces, sidewalk cafes, cool restaurants, unique shopping, and leafy parks. Sitting along the south side of the downtown Vancouver peninsula, Yaletown is bordered by Homer Street, Robson Street and False Creek.

Seeing and Doing
The waterfront parks are a big draw in Yaletown. The city’s seawall runs right along the water, connecting two of the biggest green spaces: David Lam Park and George Wainborn Park. neighborhood_overview:
Mount Pleasant is a lively and diverse neighbourhood right in the heart of Vancouver. It's famous for mixing history, culture, and modern city life in a unique way. You'll find a cool blend of homes with character and an artsy atmosphere.

Back in the day, Mount Pleasant used to be an industrial hotspot, and you can still see traces of that history. Old factories and warehouses have turned into hip lofts, shops, craft breweries, and art studios.

Wandering around, you'll notice something special about this place. It's like every street corner has its own story to tell. The walls are covered in colourful murals, there's cool art everywhere you look, and the whole neighbourhood has a laid-back, artistic vibe.

Named after the legendary "Gassy" Jack Deighton, Gastown thrives as a hub for creativity and innovation. Its streets teem with vibrant energy, attracting locals and visitors alike to explore and enjoy all it has to offer.

However, the neighborhood's dynamism also reflects an increased concentration of homelessness—a complex issue found in many urban centers. Inspired by the resilience and spirit of the community, we have committed to donating a portion of our proceeds to help feed and assist those in need in the area.

name: Home in Vancouver · 5 bedrooms · 6 beds · 5.5 baths
neighborhood_overview: In the 1960s, beachside Kitsilano was Vancouver's hippy hangout, drawing comparisons to San Francisco's Haight-Ashbury. Today, Kitsilano still has plenty of culture, but its apartments and houses are now occupied by young urban professionals and families who enjoy a modern version of that relaxed atmosphere – this is the birthplace of global yoga brand, lululemon athletica. Just over the Burrard Bridge from the downtown peninsula, the neighbourhood brings together a collection of attractions, beach and parks, residential streets, and a couple of main commercial districts. “Kits,” as it’s known locally, is bordered by the waterfront to the north and West 16th Ave to the south; Burrard Street to the east and Alma Street to the west. Most of the commercial activity is along West 4th Avenue and West Broadway, but you’ll also find shops and restaurants in the areas close to the beach.

In the nearby Village you'll find the brand new community centre, Terra Breads, London Drugs, Urban Fare, TD Canada Trust, CRAFT, and ever-popular Tap and Barrel Pub. Or, meander north, east, west and south into the fun-packed areas surrounding you.

name: Condo in Vancouver · ★4.68 · 3 bedrooms · 3 beds · 2 baths
neighborhood_overview:
Welcome to downtown Vancouver, a vibrant and dynamic neighborhood that offers a perfect blend of urban excitement and natural beauty. Situated in the heart of the city, this bustling district is a favorite among travelers seeking a memorable experience.

Urban Delights: Downtown Vancouver is a hub of cultural, culinary, and entertainment delights. Stroll through the bustling streets lined with trendy boutiques, world-class restaurants, and inviting cafes. Discover the latest fashion trends or indulge in some retail therapy at the Pacific Centre Mall, home to a wide array of international brands.

Cultural Gems: Immerse yourself in the city's rich cultural scene. Visit the Vancouver Art Gallery to admire a diverse collection of Canadian and international art. Catch a live performance at the Queen Elizabeth Theatre or enjoy a concert at the historic Orpheum Theatre. Don't miss the chance to explore the contemporary exhibits at the Vancouver Contemporary Art Gallery.

name: Place to stay in Vancouver · ★4.88 · 3 bedrooms · 3 beds · 1.5 baths
neighborhood_overview:
The Arbutus Garden suite is situated in a vibrant, busy and beautiful part of Vancouver’s west side where the three communities of Point Grey, Dunbar and Kitsilano all meet.

The best known of these communities, Kitsilano or Kits as it is known locally, offers an eclectic mix of restaurants, parks, shopping districts, multiple beaches and architectural styles ranging from single family homes to high rise apartment buildings. It is a bustling and exciting neighbourhood close to downtown but with its own unique style.

Kitsilano is also home to 17 parks including the famous Kits Beach, one of Vancouver’s most popular beaches. Here you will find not only a glorious beach, but Kitsilano Pool, Canada’s longest pool—almost three times longer than an Olympic pool.

Kitsilano offers up the best of Vancouver and all visitors, whether spending a day at the beach or strolling down 4th Avenue or Broadway, exploring the many shops or enjoying a coffee on an outdoor pat

Parking Information:

You don't need a car in Gastown - it's easy to walk around or use public transit and car-sharing services. If you do bring a car, there's a garage nearby with a daily max rate of $27 CAD. Street parking is available for two hours, but it's free from 10 PM to 9 AM. Car-sharing services like EVO are always around.

Potential Noise:

The apartment is located in a core downtown and a busy area of Gastown. There might be some outside noise. It's not completely quiet at night due to the vibrant area!

name: Condo in Vancouver · ★4.90 · Studio · 2 beds · 1 bath
neighborhood_overview:
Gastown is where you'll find the old town of Vancouver with its heritage brick buildings, Victorian architecture, cobblestone streets, and boutique shops. The famous Gastown Steam clock is a few blocks away.

While Gastown is one of Vancouver's gems, it is important to note that our Downtown core has been going through gentrification for many years.

We are steps away from some of the world's trendiest shops, restaurants, nightclubs, and attractions. However, like most vibrant cities, the surrounding area is also home to Vancouver’s edgy homeless and drug scene. You will see those less fortunate on the streets. That said, you will be completely safe as the residents of the Downtown Eastside generally keep to themselves and their own community.

Guests who stay here need to ensure they are comfortable with this knowledge. If you are not comfortable with the range of people and late-night bustle that a city brings, this may not be the place for you.

name: Rental unit in Vancouver · 1 bedroom · 1 bed · 1 bath
neighborhood_overview:
Vancouver's vibrant West End is located at the west end of downtown Vancouver, just east of Stanley Park and Lost Lagoon. The West End is surrounded by water on three sides: English Bay, Coal Harbour, and Lost Lagoon in world-famous Stanley Park.

Safeway and Whole Foods are both within a two-minute / 140m / .08mi walk from the building's front door. The entrance to Stanley Park is just a seven-minute / 550m / 0.34mi walk from the building's front door.

The West End is the heart of Vancouver's LGBTQ2S+ community, including Davie Village and Denman Street, which together provide local shopping and restaurants. This area also has high-end retail and boutique shopping on Robson Street and Alberni Street. The night life, movie theatres, and intimate concert venues on Granville Street are just a 20 minute / 1.7km / 1mi walk away.

name: Rental unit in Vancouver · ★New · 2 bedrooms · 2 beds · 1 bath
neighborhood_overview:
Kitsilano, often called "Kits," is a vibrant and trendy neighborhood located in the west side of Vancouver.

Kitsilano is known for its picturesque beaches, parks, and stunning views of the mountains and the ocean. Some of the most popular beaches in Kitsilano include Kitsilano Beach, Jericho Beach, and Spanish Banks Beach. Kitsilano Beach is particularly famous for its outdoor pool, which is open to the public from May to September each year.

The neighborhood is also home to a diverse range of shops, restaurants, cafes, and bars, many of which are located along West 4th Avenue, also known as "Kitsilano's trendy shopping district,” or West Broadway. The area is very lively with plenty of options for entertainment and socializing.

Kitsilano is a popular residential area, with a mix of heritage homes, modern condos, and apartments. It attracts a diverse population, including families, young professionals, and students from nearby universities.

name: Home in Vancouver · ★4.80 · 4 bedrooms · 5 beds · 2.5 baths
neighborhood_overview: In the 1960s, beachside Kitsilano was Vancouver's hippy hangout, drawing comparisons to San Francisco's Haight-Ashbury. Today, Kitsilano still has plenty of culture, but its apartments and houses are now occupied by young urban professionals and families who enjoy a modern version of that relaxed atmosphere – this is the birthplace of global yoga brand, lululemon athletica. Just over the Burrard Bridge from the downtown peninsula, the neighbourhood brings together a collection of attractions, beach and parks, residential streets, and a couple of main commercial districts. “Kits,” as it’s known locally, is bordered by the waterfront to the north and West 16th Ave to the south; Burrard Street to the east and Alma Street to the west. Most of the commercial activity is along West 4th Avenue and West Broadway, but you’ll also find shops and restaurants in the areas close to the beach.
